Clean implementation with proper type safety

summary: Section 11 correctly implements the core 21% flat corporate tax rate. While it's missing advanced provisions like controlled groups and personal holding companies, the implemented portion is legally accurate and immediately usable.

minor_issues: Missing many specific income types from §61(a) list beyond the core ones implemented
No cross-references to exclusions from other sections

strengths: Correctly implements the fundamental concept of gross income as 'all income from whatever source'
Comprehensive structures for different income types
Includes key items: compensation, business, gains, interest, rents, dividends, alimony, discharge of indebtedness
Proper aggregation function to calculate total gross income
Good type safety with dedicated income category types
summary: Section 61 provides a solid foundation for gross income calculation with proper modeling of major income categories. The implementation correctly captures the 'all-inclusive' nature of gross income.

summary: Section 62 correctly implements the AGI calculation concept and key deductions, but is incomplete in terms of the full range of above-the-line deductions available under §62(a).

Properly distinguishes between standard and itemized deductions
Includes QBID (§199A deduction) in taxable income calculation
Theorems prove taxable income <= AGI and other bounds
Clean mathematical structure with formal verification
summary: Section 63 accurately implements the core taxable income calculation with correct 2024 standard deduction amounts and proper integration of QBID. Excellent for standard tax calculations.

major_issues: Missing subsection (c) - Qualified principal residence exceptions and provisions beyond 2026 not fully modeled
Missing subsection (d)(7) - Real property business indebtedness election mechanics not modeled
Missing the basis reduction election under §108(b)(5) to apply reductions to depreciable property basis first
QualifiedPrincipalResidence category uses simplified date logic - actual statute has complex acquisition indebtedness limit ($750,000) and discharge timing rules

minor_issues: TaxpayerElections structure is minimal - only has one boolean for insolvency over principal residence
No modeling of §108(b)(4)(A) special ordering elections

No validation that 'written_arrangement_before_2026' actually represents a written agreement to discharge
strengths: All theorems proven without 'sorry' - code is formally verified
Core exclusion logic for Title 11 and Insolvency is correctly implemented
Attribute reduction waterfall correctly implements the 7-step sequence from §108(b)(2)
Credit reductions correctly apply 33 1/3 cents per dollar formula (divide by 3 logic)
Insolvency limitation correctly uses min(discharge_amount, insolvency_amount)
Comprehensive examples with #eval demonstrating correct arithmetic
Good separation of concerns with distinct structures for DischargeIndebtedness, TaxpayerStatus, and TaxpayerElections
Type safety through TaxYear validation (year >= 1913)
summary: Section 108 implementation covers the core discharge of indebtedness exclusions and attribute reduction rules accurately. The main calculations are correct and formally verified. However, it lacks critical provisions like the basis reduction election, complete qualified principal residence indebtedness rules (acquisition debt limits, timing), and entity-specific rules. The code is usable for basic Title 11 and insolvency scenarios but needs enhancement for real-world comprehensive tax planning. FIXED: Corrected the critical backwards C corporation logic error in QualifiedRealPropertyBusiness.

major_issues: Missing subsection (c) - reduced exclusion for failure to meet requirements due to unforeseen circumstances (health, employment, etc.) is marked as TODO in comments but not implemented
Missing subsection (d)(5)-(10) - special rules for sales involving joint returns, deceased spouses, and divorced/legally separated individuals are partially implemented
Joint return requirements in §121(b)(2)(A) have complex ownership attribution rules not fully captured
Missing the proper calculation for acquisition indebtedness that qualifies under subsection (b)(4)
minor_issues: DATE_2009_01_01 is set to Day := 0 which is arbitrary and could cause confusion in real usage
checkFrequencyLimit uses 'any' which checks if ANY prior exclusion was within 2 years - should probably check if there is NO prior exclusion within 2 years for clarity
The nonqualified use ratio calculation is complex but lacks documentation explaining the exception zone logic
Missing validation that ownership and use periods are actually for 'principal residence' vs other uses
spouseDeathDate handling in QualifyingWidower status could be more robust
No modeling of divorced spouse rules where property transferred in divorce is treated as owned/used by receiving spouse during marriage
strengths: All theorems proven without 'sorry' - fully verified code
Ownership and use tests correctly implement '2 out of 5 years' lookback period (730 days out of 1825 days)
Joint return requirements properly check ownership (either spouse), use (both spouses), and frequency (neither spouse)
Exclusion limits correctly distinguish $250,000 vs $500,000 based on filing status and joint return requirements
Nonqualified use ratio calculation implements the 2009 exception properly - only post-2009 periods count, and excludes the final 5 years after last use
Time period intersection logic is mathematically sound
Theorems prove that excluded gain does not exceed the statutory limit or total gain
Complex rational number arithmetic for nonqualified use properly uses Rat.divInt and floor functions
summary: Section 121 implementation is mathematically sophisticated and correctly implements the core principal residence exclusion rules including ownership/use tests, exclusion limits, joint return requirements, and the complex nonqualified use calculations. The code is formally verified with sound theorems. However, it lacks the reduced exclusion provisions for unforeseen circumstances (subsection c) and some special rules for divorced/deceased spouse scenarios. It's highly usable for standard principal residence sales but needs enhancements for edge cases.

The treatment of different ownership types (life tenant, trust, estate, term interest) is sophisticated and correct. Basis adjustment mechanics for term interests are properly modeled. While it doesn't implement actual depreciation method calculations, the foundational framework is strong and legally accurate.

summary: Section 199 (Domestic production activities deduction) correctly models specific historical provisions that were in effect before repeal. While the section is now mostly irrelevant for current tax years, the formalization accurately captures the termination dates and the limited provisions implemented (oil refiner transportation costs and Puerto Rico rules). Useful for historical tax analysis but not for current planning.

The mathematics are correct, edge cases are handled (short trips, small gifts), and the code is formally verified. This is production-quality code ready for real tax calculations.

summary: Section 301 implementation is excellent and accurately captures the core distribution mechanics. The amount distributed calculation, liability reductions, and three-tier taxable treatment are all correctly implemented and formally verified. The theorems prove mathematical correctness of the decomposition. While it lacks some advanced provisions like §312 earnings and profits coordination and §318 constructive ownership, the implemented provisions are legally accurate and immediately usable for standard corporate distribution analysis.

summary: Section 1001 (Determination of gain or loss) has no implementation - only TODOs. This is THE foundational section for all capital transactions (Gain = Amount Realized - Adjusted Basis). Without this, no capital gains taxation can be calculated. Absolutely critical for rerun.

summary: Section 1221 (Capital asset defined) has no implementation - only TODOs. This definitional section determines whether gain/loss receives capital or ordinary treatment, affecting tax rates significantly. The 'capital asset' definition (property EXCEPT inventory, depreciables, etc.) is critical for proper tax treatment. Essential for rerun.

The percentage calculation correctly implements the dual phaseout structure (Part A: 50%→35%, Part B: further reduction to 20%). While missing the earned income limitation and some edge cases, the core credit calculation is production-ready and legally accurate.

summary: Section 408 (Individual Retirement Accounts) provides solid formalization of IRA, annuity, and employer trust requirements. The core qualification rules are accurate: cash contributions only (except rollovers), contribution limits, no life insurance, nonforfeitability, and proper trustees. While it lacks RMD rules, Roth IRAs, and detailed distribution provisions, the implemented portions correctly model the foundational IRA qualification requirements and are suitable for basic IRA compliance checking.
